FacilityName: Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC is a refined petroleum product distributor.  The Tampa LP Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Tampa, FL.  The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel/#2 Fuel Oil, butane, ethanol, asphalt and various other petroleum based additives.

Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC (Marathon) in Tampa, FL is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner.  Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Tampa LP Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community.  Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection.  These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has designed and implemented including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The butane blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects asso

ciated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions during handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Tampa LP Terminal - Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Tampa LP Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular/blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via an automated analyzer and process controls. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, fusible elements on pneumatic valves (fail safe), fill shutoff on the vessel, manual and automatic emergency shutoff devices on the system, HMI system display at terminal office, pressure and hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Tampa LP Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors as governed by the U.S. Coast Guard.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

The Tampa LP Terminal accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning/response programs help Marathon effectively manage the hazards posed by the regulated substance to the Terminal employees, surrounding public, and environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119.  MPLX Terminals, LLC is also volu

d safety inspections and audits; and 
-Frequent unit surveillance by operators.

General Release Mitigation

-Automatic and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity;
-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks;
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release; and
-Fire monitors installed at the butane storage vessel and offload area.

General Emergency Response

-Emergency alert system;
-Periodic emergency training for employees;
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; and
-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Tampa LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with Tampa Fire Rescue and Hillsborough County Office of Emergency Management.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Tampa LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated, follow-up actions. There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

As previously noted, the Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Tampa Fire Rescue and Hillsborough County Office of Emergency Management.  An ERAP (part of a comprehensive "Smart Plan") is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release or fire along with response notification procedures.

In the event of an emergency involving the Tampa LP Terminal butane b

lending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Tampa Fire Rescue and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire and 1st Responder Operations capability. The Tampa Fire Rescue has participated in butane training sessions for this system (initially at startup and annully.)

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Marathon is continually striving to make the Tampa LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Marathon actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements.  All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT).  The Tampa Fire Rescue is contacted annually regarding participation in site emergency response training and/or drills. Additionally, Marathon will work cooperatively with the community, local industry and response agencies to address concerns and emergency preparedness.
